Name: Carpropamid
Description: Carpropamid is a cyclopropylcarboxamide obtained by formal condensation of the carboxy group of 2,2-dichloro-1-ethyl-3-methylcyclopropanecarboxylic acid with the amino group of 1-(4-chlorophenyl)ethylamine. A rice fungicide with specific action against Pyricularia oryzae. It is not highly toxic to mammals but shows a moderate level of toxicity to birds, fish and earthworms. It has a role as an EC 4.2.1.94 (scytalone dehydratase) inhibitor, a xenobiotic, a melanin synthesis inhibitor and an antifungal agrochemical. It is a cyclopropylcarboxamide, a member of monochlorobenzenes and an amide fungicide.

plant_translocations.content: Translocation of the antiblast compound carpropamid was investigated in rice using [^14C]carpropamid. When applied to the seed, carpropamid was not only readily absorbed but also translocated to different parts of the seedlings emerging from treated seeds. A substantial portion of the fungicide appeared to be exuded onto the leaf surface. In 21-day-old plants grown from [^14C]carpropamid-treated seeds, 27.2% of the radioactivity isolated from leaves was present on the surface of the lamina. This exuded fraction is probably responsible for its action as a fungal anti-penetrant compound. Following a 30-minute root dipping of 14-day-old seedlings, carpropamid was rapidly absorbed and translocated throughout the seedling. Its intralamellar distribution was uniform as determined by autoradiography. Only a small fraction (<2%) of the fungicide applied to the foliage was translocated beyond the site of application within the treated leaf. Translocation was primarily apoplastic. Approximately 54% of the radioactivity recovered from leaves was in the form of carpropamid. At least seven radiolabeled metabolic products were observed by TLC. Only 8.3% of the radioactivity applied through the seeds could be recovered from 21-day-old seedlings.
plant_translocations.reference: Rohilla, R., Singh, U. S., & Singh, R. L. (2001). Uptake and translocation of carpropamid in rice (Oryza sativa L). Pest Management Science: formerly Pesticide Science, 57(3), 239-247.

method.Test Plant: Rice (Oryza sativa L. cv. Pusa Basmati-1)
method.Plant Grown Condition: Grown from seeds in 15 cm plastic pots in soil amended with 30 mg N, 9.7 mg P, 18.5 mg K per kg soil. Raised in greenhouse at 25±3°C. Thinned to 7 seedlings per pot
method.Chemical Preparation: [Phenyl-14C]carpropamid (6.73 MBq/mg specific activity) dissolved in 0.2 mL acetone, diluted to 4 mL with water. Test solutions prepared by mixing radiolabeled and unlabeled carpropamid 300 g/kg SC formulation. Final application solution was 444 mg AI/L containing 0.093 MBq/mL [14C]carpropamid
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: 100 μL of 444 mg AI/L carpropamid solution applied to 3rd leaf lamina of 30-day-old plants. Pre-treated with 50 μL 20 g/L gelatin to aid spreading .Applied in small droplets, spread evenly with micropipette tip 12.5:11.5 h day:night conditions
method.Other Information: Samples harvested at 6, 18, 30, 54, 94 h after treatment. Treated leaves, roots washed and autoradiographed. Radioactivity extracted from plant parts with methanol. 3 replicates with 3 plants each per treatment
